contentrichtext.text: '''Ternary form''', sometimes called '''song form''',<ref name="HD2nd binary and ternary" /> is a three-part [[musical form]], usually schematized as A–B–A. The first and third parts (A) are musically identical, or very nearly so, while the second part (B) in some way provides a contrast with them. The B section is often called the ''trio'', especially in [[minuet]]s and [[scherzo|scherzi]].<ref name="HD2nd trio (2)" /> Examples include [[Robert Schumann|Schumann]]'s "Folk Song", ''[[Album for the Young]]'' (Op. 68, No. 9) and [[Frédéric Chopin|Chopin]]'s [[Prelude, Op. 28, No. 15 (Chopin)|Prelude in D-Flat Major]] (Op. 28).<ref>White, John D. (1976). ''The Analysis of Music'', pp. 53–54. ISBN 0-13-033233-X.</ref> ==Characteristics== In ternary form, unlike the rounded [[binary form]], each section will usually be self-contained both [[theme (music)|thematically]] and [[tonality|tonally]] (that is, each section contains distinct and complete themes, and ends with an [[cadence (music)#Authentic cadence|authentic cadence]].<ref name="HD2nd binary and ternary" /> The B section is generally in a contrasting, but [[closely related key]], usually the [[dominant key]] of the first section's [[tonic (music)|tonic]] (a [[perfect fifth]] above) or the [[Relative key|relative]] or [[Parallel key|parallel]] minor or major,<ref name="HD2nd binary and ternary" /> less often the [[subdominant]] key (a perfect fifth below). It usually also has a contrasting character; in a [[march (music)|march]], for example, the highly rhythmic and strident character of the march itself is usually contrasted with a more lyrical and flowing trio in the subdominant, and often in a [[Triple metre|3/4]] [[time signature]] as opposed to the 4/4 of the primary march theme.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} A distinction is sometimes made{{by whom?|date=August 2011}} between "compound ternary form" – in which each large part of the form is itself divided in a way to suggest ternary or binary form (giving, for example, an overall scheme of {{Nowrap|A–B–A–C–D–C–A–B–A)}} – and "simple ternary form", in which each large part of the form has no particular structure itself. [[Da capo aria|''Da capo'' arias]] are usually in simple ternary form; minuets (or scherzos) and trios are normally compound {{Nowrap|[(1A–1A–1B–1B) (2A–2A-2B-2B) (1A-1B)]}}. Another name for the latter is "composite ternary form".{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} The repetition of any section results in ''expanded ternary form''.<ref name="Benward & Saker" /> Commonly, the third section will feature more ornamentation than the first section (as is often the case with ''da capo'' arias). In these cases the last section is sometimes labeled A’ or A1 to indicate that it is slightly different from the first A section.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} ==Usage== As well as in marches, ternary form is often found in [[baroque music|baroque]] [[opera]] [[aria]]s (the ''da capo'' aria) and in many dance forms, such as [[polka]]s. It is also the form used in the minuet (or scherzo) and trio, which, in the [[Classical period (music)|Classical era]], was usually the third movement of [[symphony|symphonies]], [[string quartet]]s, [[sonata]]s and similar works.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} ==See also== *[[Thirty-two-bar form]] ==Sources== {{reflist|refs= <ref name="HD2nd binary and ternary">"Binary and ternary form" in the ''Harvard Dictionary of Music'', 2nd ed. rev. and enlarged (1969).
